issue.title: Removing delay extensions

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

issue.body:
fixes #5076 

Completely removes delay extensions and all related code.

issue.title: Sidekiq 7.0 changes

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

issue.body:
This branch holds all pending Sidekiq 7.0 changes. There is no timeline and we are still months away from release. Assume Summer 2022.

- [x] #5076
- [x] remove redis-namespace
- [x] Require Ruby 2.7+, Rails 6+
- [x] Require Redis 6.2+ (available since 3/21)
- [x] Transaction-aware client [#5239]
- [x] Migrate to new, simpler [redis-client](https://github.com/redis-rb/redis-client/) project [#5253]
- [x] Drop `constantize` ([rails pr](https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/41877))
- [x] Enable strict argument checking by default, `Sidekiq.strict_args!(:raise | :warn | false)`
- [x] Prepare Sidekiq Pro 6.0
- [x] Prepare Sidekiq Enterprise 3.0
- [ ] Write release notes and blog post.

body:
We rely heavily on the delayed class extensions as a pattern to easily run any function async.
(I've have mixed feelings about it since I know what it does under the hood with the YAML un/marshalling, but it sure is convenient.)

I expect I won't be the only person looking for some discussion of an upgrade path, so I thought I'd mention it here.

I think for the most part we should be able to change

```ruby
class User
  def self.call_me(*args, **options)
    #
  end

  def self.call_me_async(*args, **options)
    delay_for(1.minute, retry: 0, queue: :default).call_me(*args, **options)
  end

  def call_me_async
    self.class.call_me_async
  end
end
```

to use a regular worker with something like

```ruby
class GenericWorker < ApplicationWorker

  def _perform(klass_name, *args)
    klass = klass_name.constantize
    options = extract_options!(args)
    if options
      logger.info "[#{jid}] GenericWorker executing #{klass_name}.public_send(*#{args.inspect}, **#{options.inspect})"
      klass.public_send(*args, **options)
    else
      logger.info "[#{jid}] GenericWorker executing #{klass_name}.public_send(*#{args.inspect})"
      klass.public_send(*args)
    end
  end
end
```

and changing the User code to

```diff
    def self.call_me_async(*args, **options)
-     delay_for(1.minute, retry: 0, queue: :default).call_me(*args, **options)
+     GenericWorker.set(retry: 0, queue: :default).perform_in(1.minute, model_name.name, :call_me, *args, **options)
    end
```

and our test helpers would change something like

```diff
  def sidekiq_delayed_jobs
    sidekiq_worker_class.jobs
  end

  def sidekiq_worker_class
-    Sidekiq::Extensions::DelayedClass
+    GenericWorker
  end

  def sidekiq_job_attributes(sidekiq_job)
-    # @note Yes, this is unsafe
-    YAML.unsafe_load(sidekiq_job["args"].first)
+    JSON.parse(sidekiq_job["args"].first)
  end
```

I have no problem with the delayed extensions going into a 3rd party gem which maintains the exact same API. I just donâ€™t want them in core anymore. This could be as simple as:

gem â€œsidekiq-delayâ€

Or whatever.

@bf4 please let me know if and when "sidekiq-delay" becomes a reality ðŸ˜„ 

I like the idea of getting rid of YAML too ðŸ¤”
I'm willing to do the work to extract the delayed extensions into a gem, but I'm not really interested in maintaining it, so not sure what good that does anyone.

issue.title: Extract Sidekiq::DelayExtensions
issue.body:
per https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/issues/5076

note https://rubygems.org/gems/sidekiq-delay exists, so naming sidekiq_delayed_extensions

body:
I took a stab at extracting the delayed extensions in https://github.com/gemhome/sidekiq-delay_extensions/pull/1

Got one failing test, but most of the changes are bulk code wrangling. I haven't reviewed the full changeset at this time for correctness.

My intention would be to release in lockstep with sidekiq until 7.0, at which point it would possibly begin to diverge

If it works out, I'll push it to rubygems.  PRS welcome

Got tests passing. And happy enough with it to release as https://rubygems.org/gems/sidekiq-delay_extensions
Only 6.4.0 and 6.4.1 right now

What's the new recommended way to interact with ActionMailer? The only place it's referenced in the wiki is showing [how to use it with delayed extensions](https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/wiki/Delayed-extensions#actionmailer).
The idiomatic Rails way is deliver_later.

> The idiomatic Rails way is deliver_later.

Thanks. I know you're not a big fan of ActiveJob so I wanted to see if there was some other method that you recommended instead.

issue.title: 3384 â€“ update rails to ~> 6.1.7

repository.name: pender
repository.description: URL parsing, archiving and rendering service for Meedan Check, a collaborative media annotation platform

issue.body:
## Description

Thereâ€™s a CVE for actionpack in Pender that should be resolved by us upgrading Rails to 6.1.74 (or just doing ~>6.1.7 and upgrading)

References: cv2-3384

## How has this been tested?

Ran a request to `pender`, like the one below, got the parsed response ðŸŽ‰ 
```
curl -X GET -H 'X-Pender-Token: dev' -H 'Content-type: application/json' http://localhost:3200/api/medias.json?url=https://www.tiktok.com/@flowerboyjoy&refresh=1
```

## Things to pay attention to during code review

Although a tiny change, a few things broke:

- Sidekiq: it was initially bumped to 7, but since that one doesn't support `delayed extensions` anymore, I kept it under that. However, we use that in one place, it doesn't look like it will be super hard to upgrade(ðŸ¤ž). Seems to be setup [here (03_sidekiq.rb#L27)](https://github.com/meedan/pender/blob/3384-update-rails-to-6.1.7.4/config/initializers/03_sidekiq.rb#L27) and used [here(media_archive_org_archiver.rb#L28)](https://github.com/meedan/pender/blob/3384-update-rails-to-6.1.7.4/app/models/concerns/media_archive_org_archiver.rb#L28).
- Addressable/Postrank: kept addressable at 2.8.1, after that version there is an issue with Postrank, and we are not able to run `uri.normalize`

**relevant links / sidekiq's upgrade**
- https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/blob/main/Changes.md#640
- https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/issues/5076
- https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/blob/main/docs/7.0-Upgrade.md
- https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/blob/main/docs/7.0-API-Migration.md

**relevant links / addressable issue**
- https://github.com/sporkmonger/addressable/issues/513
- https://github.com/sporkmonger/addressable/issues/506
- https://github.com/postrank-labs/postrank-uri/issues/49

issue.title: Support Sidekiq 7 and deprecate be_delayed matcher

milestone.title: v4.0.0
milestone.description:
1. ðŸ§¹  Bring RSpec up-to-date with Ruby Versions, Sidekiq Versions, and Rails Versions.
2. ðŸ› Fix some long-outstanding bugs
3. ðŸ™ Add block syntax

issue.body:
`delayed` extensions where [removed entirely from Sidekiq 7](https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/issues/5076)

As such, we should consider that matcher deprecated. However, both the lib (and local tests/dev) should support it so long as we support Sidekiq <7.

Additionally, this should also drop support for Sidekiq <5.

issue.title: Add support to sidekiq-delay_extensions

labels.name: community
labels.description: To tag external issues and PRs submitted by the community

issue.body:
_Before contributing, please read our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/newrelic/newrelic-ruby-agent/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) and [code of conduct](https://github.com/newrelic/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)._

# Overview
`Sidekiq::Extensions::DelayedClass` got removed on https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/issues/5076 but a gem was created to support that feature: https://github.com/gemhome/sidekiq-delay_extensions

We are adding the instrumentation as we had for the native extensions.

Submitter Checklist:
- [ ] Include a link to the related GitHub issue, if applicable
- [ ] Include a security review link, if applicable

# Testing
The agent includes a suite of unit and functional tests which should be used to
verify your changes don't break existing functionality. These tests will run with 
GitHub Actions when a pull request is made. More details on running the tests locally can be found 
[here for our unit tests](https://github.com/newrelic/newrelic-ruby-agent/blob/main/test/README.md), 
and [here for our functional tests](https://github.com/newrelic/newrelic-ruby-agent/blob/main/test/multiverse/README.md).
For most contributions it is strongly recommended to add additional tests which
exercise your changes. 

# Reviewer Checklist
- [ ] Perform code review
- [ ] Add performance label
- [ ] Perform appropriate level of performance testing
- [ ] Confirm all checks passed
- [ ] Add version label prior to acceptance
